results.title: Bet your life
results.creator_credit: Mike Woolveridge, Don Anderson, Barry Pierce, Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
A 1980 film that encourages safe practices for workers on construction sites. The film presents examples of common factors that lead to industrial accidents, in occupations including electricians, carpenters, metal workers and bricklayers. Opening with scenes of a funeral, and presenting dramatic sequences of each accident, the narrator introduces each character and the careless practices leading to mishaps, dangerous accidents and death.

Produced by the Tasmania Film Corporation for the Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: You can't shift the blame
results.creator_credit: Mike Woolveridge, Jack Zalkalns, Barry Pierce, Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
This 1980 film focuses on safety practices for operating mobile cranes and warns against the main types of mishaps and accidents that can occur. The film dramatises the importance of maintenance; setting up on solid ground; load charts and labels; and the role of the ‘dogman’ who directs the operation of the crane from near the load. The voiceover’s tone is casual and familiar, with use of colloquial terms such as ‘galah’. The footage of worksites is introduced and interspersed with an interview with a department official, reflecting on the dangerous and fatal accidents that have occurred.

Produced by the Tasmanian Film Corporation for the Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Wool: an exhibition of the Art Gallery of South Australia, Adelaide Festival of Arts, 1972
results.creator_credit: Brian Kavanagh, Art Gallery of South Australia and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The versatility of wool is applied to artistic tapestries and home decor furnishings. Used by highly creative craftspeople, wool is knotted, twisted or woven, bunched and crunched, looped or drooped - to assemble many exciting textured designs. The film is centred on the creative applications of this exciting raw material. After a short voice-over introduction, the sound track is a series of inspired tone poems composed by the noted jazz musician Don Burrows and performed by his Quintet. The film includes exhibits by Judith Barnes, Robert Bell, Fay Bottrell, Arthur Boyd, John Coburn, Deanna Conti, John Olsen and others.

results.title: Art makes people
results.creator_credit: Rona Saunders and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A film designed to show that the experience of art education has an important place in the growth of the individual. The film is highly stylised and shows a young child growing and moving through a series of “rooms” encountering various art/educational experiences until she/he emerges to face the world. Includes original music composed and performed by Jim Beattie.

results.title: Touch wood: five Tasmanian woodworkers
results.brief_description: About five men who live in Tasmania and earn their living by working with wood. David Ralph makes small souvenir animals and furniture from horizontal wood; Kevin Perkins makes furniture which allows the natural shape of the wood to be shown; Merv Gray and Peter Mevre make bowls and spheres, and Peter Taylor sculptural pieces.

results.title: Beginning silk screening on fabric (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Brenton Holmes, Open College of Further Education (S. Aust.) and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: This program demonstrates the basic procedures for silk-screening on to fabric using paper stencils. Building a frame, attaching the silk, preparing stencils and making a two-colour print are shown

results.title: Neon
results.creator_credit: Salik Silverstein, Alex Proyas and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A single-frame time-lapse journey through Sydney, the surrealistic city. Figures dart in and out of the shadows of the night. A kaleidoscope of imagery flies by - incorporates people in subways, cars on freeways, city streets and buildings. The music (by Fad Gadget) drives the images to a tumultuous climax.

results.title: The Repco-Brabham story
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Thompson and Cine Service Production
results.brief_description: Briefly shows manufacture and testing of racing cars by the Brabham Racing Organisation in England, followed by views of the 1965 Tasman Series motor races in Australia and New Zealand, Jack Brabham and others competing in Brabham cars. Finally, manufacture of a new Repco engine in Australia is shown.

Finally, manufacture of a new Repco engine in Australia is shown.

results.title: The Rigid Heddle Frame
results.creator_credit: Ken J. Widdowson, John Gray and Educational Media
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Weaving”.
An instructional film on weaving for both beginners and more advanced weavers. In the rigid heddle frame, warp threads are passed through a slotted, wooden heddle instead of being attached to moving cords. Additional credits: photographer: Alan Grice ; script: Kay Donald ; editor: David Corke ; weaver and adviser: Erika Semler.

results.title: Nippers, chompers, grinders
results.creator_credit: Judy Nelson and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: A film on dental hygiene for children ages 5-8. Janis, who refuses to brush her teeth, disappears down the plughole in order to escape that boring task. She meets three monsters, Nippers, Chompers and Grinders, each with specific tooth ailments and helps them overcome their disabilities. Voices: Valma Bolton, Colin Van Cao, Evelyn Krape, Stephen Radic, Claire Dobbin.
